statement.p: A weather balloon is rising vertically at the rate of 10. An observer is standing on the ground 300 horizontally from the point where the balloon was released. At what rate is the distance between the observer and the balloon changing when the balloon is 400 height?

solution.p: First we make a diagram of the situation.
Next we account for the various quantities and rates in the problem.

table.caption: Variable table for the balloon problem

row.cell: Variable
Variable Description
Unit
How far the balloon has risen since it was released.
How far is the observer from the balloon t seconds after it was released.
The rate at which the balloon is rising.
The rate at which the distance between the observer and the balloon is changing.

table.caption: What we know about the variables at the described moment

row.cell: Variable
What we know
The value of this variable is 400.
The value of this variable is d=\sqrt{300^2+400^2}=500.
The value of this variable is 10.
This is the variable for which we need to solve.

solution.p: Now we can substitute these values into the related rates equation and solve for \lz{d}{t}. d\lz{d}{t}&=h\lz{h}{t} 500\lz{d}{t}&=400(10) \lz{d}{t}&=8 So when the balloon is 400 in the air, the distance between the observer and the balloon is increasing at a rate of 8.

statement.p: At 2:00 PM one day, Muffin and Rex were sleeping atop one another. A loud noise startled the animals and Muffin began to run due north at a constant rate of 1.7 while Rex ran due east at a constant rate of 2.1. The critters maintained these paths and rates for several seconds. Calculate the rate at which the distance between the cat and dog was changing three seconds into their run.

solution.p: First we make a diagram of the situation.
Next we account for the various quantities and rates in the problem.

table.caption: Variable table for the Rex-Muffin problem

row.cell: Variable
Variable Description
Unit
How far Rex has run t seconds after the loud noise.
How far Muffin has run t seconds after the loud noise.
The distance between Muffin and Rex t seconds after the loud noise.
The rate at which Rex is running t seconds after the loud noise.
The rate at which Muffin is running t seconds after the loud noise.
The rate at which the distance between Rex and Muffin is changing t seconds after the loud noise.

table.caption: What we know about the variables at the described moment

row.cell: Variable
What we know
The value of this variable is 3\cdot2.1=6.3.
The value of this variable is 3\cdot1.7=5.1.
Using the diagram and the Pythagorean Theorem, we find that d=\sqrt{6.3^2+5.1^2}\approx8.105\ldots.
The value of this variable is 2.1.
The value of this variable is 1.7.
This is the variable for which we need to solve.

solution.p: Now we can substitute these values into the related rates equation and solve for \lz{d}{t}. 2d\lz{d}{t}&=2x\lz{x}{t}+\lz{y}{t} 2(8.105\ldots)\lz{d}{t}&=2(6.3)(2.1)+2(5.1)(1.7) 16.21\ldots\lz{d}{t}&=43.8 \lz{d}{t}&\approx2.701\ldots So 3 after the animals begin to run, their distance apart from each other is increasing at a rate of approximately 2.701.

statement.p: Schuyler's clock is kaput; the minute hand functions as it should but the hour hand is stuck at 4. The minute hand on the clock is 30 long and the hour hand is 20 long. Determine the rate of change between the tips of the hands every time the minute hand points directly at 12.

solution.p: First we make a diagram of the situation.
Next we account for the various quantities and rates in the problem.

table.caption: Variable table for the clock problem

row.cell: Variable
Variable Description
Unit
The distance between the tips of the hands at time t.
The angle from the minute hand to the hour hand at time t.
The rate at which the distance between the tips of the hands at time t is changing.
The rate at which the angle from the minute hand to the hour hand at time t is changing.

table.caption: What we know about the variables at the described moment

row.cell: Variable
What we know
The value of this variable is found using the Law of Cosines: d=\sqrt{30^2+20^2-2(30)(20)\fe{\cos}{\frac{2\pi}{3}}}\approx43.58\ldots.
The value of this variable is \frac{2\pi}{3}.
This is the variable for which we need to solve.

The value of this variable is -\frac{2\pi}{60}, since the minute hand goes through an entire revolution every 60. It is negative, because at the moment we are investigating, the minute hand is moving closer to the hour hand.

solution.p: Now we can substitute these values into the related rates equation and solve for \lz{d}{t}. 2d\lz{d}{t}&=1200\fe{\sin}{\theta}\lz{\theta}{t} 2(43.58\ldots)\lz{d}{t}&\approx1200\fe{\sin}{\frac{2\pi}{3}}(-\frac{2\pi}{60}) 87.17\ldots\lz{d}{t}&\approx-108.8\ldots \lz{d}{t}&\approx-1.248\ldots So when the minute hand reaches the 12, the distance betwen the tips of the two hands is decreasing at a rate of about 1.248.

statement.p: It was a dark night and 5.5 tall Bahram was walking towards a street lamp whose light was perched 40 into the air. As he walked, the light caused a shadow to fall behind Bahram. When Bahram was 80 from the base of the lamp he was walking at a pace of 2. At what rate was the length of Bahram's shadow changing at that instant? Make sure that each stated and calculated rate value has the correct sign. Make sure that your conclusion sentence clearly communicates whether the length of the shadow was increasing or decreasing at the indicated time.

solution.p: First we make a diagram of the situation.
Next we account for the various quantities and rates in the problem.

table.caption: Variable table for the shadow problem

row.cell: Variable
Variable Description
Unit
The distance from the lamp base to wher Bahram is standing at time t.
The length of Bahram's shadow at time t.
The rate at which Bahram's distance from the base of the lamp post is changing at time t.
The rate at which the length of Bahram's shadow is changing at time t.

table.caption: What we know about the variables at the described moment

row.cell: Variable
What we know
The value of this variable is 80.
The value of this variable could be found using the similar triangles quation, but since this variable does not appear in the related rates equation, there is no need to find its value.
Since Bahram is walking with a pace of 2 \emph{toward} the lamp, the value of this variable is -2.
This is the variable for which we must solve.

statement.p: The gravitational force, F, between two objects in space with masses m_1 and m_2 is given by the formula F=\frac{Gm_1m_2}{r^2} where r is the distance between the objects' centers of mass and G is the universal gravitational constant.

Two pieces of space junk, one with mass 500 and the other with mass 3000, were drifting directly toward one another. When the objects' centers of mass were 250 apart the lighter piece was moving at a rate of 0.5 and the heavier piece was moving at a rate of 0.9. Leaving G as a constant, determine the rate at which the gravitational force between the two objects was changing at that instant. Make sure that each stated and calculated rate value has the correct sign. Make sure that your conclusion sentence clearly communicates whether the force was increasing or decreasing at that given time. The unit for F is Newtons ().

answer.p: 0.2688G newtons per our, for G measured in

solution.p: We don't really need a diagram here, since the equation relating the various quantities has been given. Accounting for the various quantities and rates in the problem:

table.caption: Variable table for the shadow problem

row.cell: Variable
Variable Description
Unit
The distance between the two objects' centers of mass at time t.
The gravitaional force between the two objects at time t.
The rate at which the distance between the two objects' centers of mass is changing at time t.
The rate at which the gravitaional force between the two objects is changing at time t.

table.caption: What we know about the variables at the described moment

row.cell: Variable
What we know
The value of this variable is 250.
This variable does not appear in the related rates equation, so we do not need to compute it.
The value of this variable is negative, since the objecta are getting closer to each other. Given their speeds at the moment under consideration, the value of \lz{r}{t} is -(0.9+0.5)=-1.4.
This is the variable for which we must solve.

solution.p: Now we can substitute these values into the related rates equation and solve for \lz{F}{t}. \lz{F}{t}=-\frac{3000000G}{r^3}\cdot\lz{r}{t} \lz{F}{t}=-\frac{3000000G}{250^3}\cdot(-1.4) \lz{F}{t}=0.2688G So at the moment when the objects are 250 apart, the gravitational force between them is increasing at a rate of 0.2688G newtons per hour. (G is measured in .)

statement.p: An eighteen inch pendulum sitting atop a table is in the downward part of its motion. The pivot point for the pendulum is 30 above the table top. When the pendulum is 45 away from vertical, the angle formed at the pivot is decreasing at the rate of 25. At what rate is the end of the pendulum approaching the table top at this instant? Make sure that each stated and calculated rate value has the correct sign. Make sure that you use appropriate units when defining your variables.

solution.p: First we make a diagram of the situation.

Next we account for the various quantities and rates in the problem. Note that an angle and an angle rate were given in terms of degrees, but we should convert to radians because the derivatives that we are familiar with for trigonometric functions assume that radians are in use.

table.caption: Variable table for the shadow problem

row.cell: Variable
Variable Description
Unit
The angle between the pendulum and the vertical.
The distance from the pendulum weight to the table.
The rate at which the angle between the pendulum and the vertical is changing at time t.
The rate at which the distance from the pendulum weight to the table is changing at time t.

table.caption: What we know about the variables at the described moment

row.cell: Variable
What we know
The value of this variable is \frac{\pi}{4}.
This variable does not appear in the related rates equation, so there is no need to solve for it.
The value of this variable is -25\frac{\pi}{180}, or just -\frac{5}{36}\pi.
This is the variable for which we must solve.
